r_compare_distributions.py - statistical test for distributions¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

This script compares two distributions from two samples of data. If only one sample is given, the sample can be compared the normal distribution.

The tests are implemented in R.

Usage¶

Example:

python r_compare_distributions.py --help

Type:

python r_compare_distributions.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: r_compare_distributions.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  -m METHOD, --method=METHOD
                        method to use: ks=Kolmogorov-Smirnov, mwu=Mann-
                        WhitneyU, shapiro=Shapiro-Wilk, paired-mwu=paired
                        Mann-WhitneyU, paired-t=paired t-test [default=ks]
  -a FILE, --hardcopy=FILE
                        write hardcopy to file.
  -1 FILENAME_INPUT1, --infile1=FILENAME_INPUT1
                        input filename for distribution 1.
  -2 FILENAME_INPUT2, --infile2=FILENAME_INPUT2
                        input filename for distribution 2.
  --legend=LEGEND       legend for histograms.
  -f FILENAME_INPUT_MAP, --infile-map=FILENAME_INPUT_MAP
                        input filename for mapping categories to values.
  -n, --norm-test       test if a set of values is normally distributed. Mean
                        and variance
                                               are calculated from the data.
  -b NUM_BINS, --num-bins=NUM_BINS
                        number of bins (for plotting purposes only).
  --bin-size=BIN_SIZE   bin size for plot.
  --min-value=MIN_VALUE
                        minimum_value for plot.
  --max-value=MAX_VALUE
                        maximum_value for plot.
  --skip-plot           skipping plotting.
  --header=HEADER       header of value column [default=value].
  --title=TITLE         plot title [default=none].
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -C PSQL_CONNECTION, --connection=PSQL_CONNECTION
                        psql connection string [fgu202:postgres].
  -U USER, --user=USER  database user name [].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
